newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: African students in Bangladesh protest attack.
newsitem.headline: African students in Bangladesh protest attack.

text.p: African students at a technical institute near Dhaka marched to the office of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina on Wednesday to protest against what they called racially motivated attacks by Bangladeshi villagers.

"We feel deeply hurt and disappointed that we face such problems in a country that claims brotherhood among Moslems, and has won the sympathy of all African countries," the protesters said in a memorandum handed to the prime minister's office.
When told that Hasina was not in her office, the students squatted outside and chanted: "Where is Islamic brotherhood?" and "We want justice and protection."
Earlier the Africans marched to embassies of Moslem countries in the Bangladesh capital and handed out copies of the memorandum, police said.
African students at the Islamic Institute of Technology at Tongi, 25 km (15 miles) from Dhaka, began boycotting classes on Wednesday after two colleagues were injured in an assault.
Ibrahim Bande, chairman of the African Students Union at the institute, said the Africans felt insecure following the attack by villagers on two Senegalese students on Tuesday night.
Abdoulie Gieng and Usman (one name) suffered severe head injuries, Bande said. Both were admitted to hospital.
"They faced a racial attack by local people as they ventured to a market outside the campus," he told Reuters.
"This is the sixth case of this nature," said the memorandum, adding that Bangladeshi authorities had done nothing about the incidents.

Professor Abdul Matin Patwari, director general of the institute, confirmed that "minor clashes" between students and outsiders had occurred, but dismissed allegations that they were racially motivated.
"The information I got was that the clashes occurred over price-bargaining during shopping, not that people were attacked only because they are black," he told Reuters.
"They are from totally different cultures. So there might be some misunderstanding and suspicion," he added.
Patwari said he had spoken to community leaders in an attempt to prevent further incidents. He also said he had called in police to guard the campus.
The 70 Africans are the biggest group among 350 students of the institute, which is funded by member countries of the Organisation of Islamic Conference.
